metadata.case_name: Masud Khan v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioner came to India from Pakistan on the basis of a Pakistani passport dated 13-7-1954 and Indian visa dated 9-4-1956.

In his application for visa, petitioner stated that he had migrated to Pakistan in 1948 and was in Government service in Pakistan in P.W.D. as a Darogha and had given his permanent address as Hyderabad Sind.

Petitioner filed further affidavit stating he was appointed as a Police Constable in Hasanganj Police Station, District Fatehpur, U.P. in February 1947 and continued as a Police Constable till the middle of 1950 when he was dismissed from service, and that he went to Pakistan in the year 1951.
In reply affidavit, respondent stated that one Md. Masood Khan son of Zahoor Khan was enrolled as Police Constable on 16-9-1947 and he was discharged from service on 20-5-1949.
Petitioner alleged that he was married in U.P. on 25th December, 1949.
In 1960, petitioner was prosecuted before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Fatehpur under s. 14 of the Foreigners Act and was acquitted on the ground that he was not a foreigner.
Petitioner illegally arrested and confined to jail under Paragraph 5 of the Foreigners Internment Order, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether the petitioner is an Indian citizen or a foreigner.
Whether the petitioner has discharged the burden under s.9 of the Foreigners Act to prove he is not a foreigner.
Whether issue estoppel arises from the 1960 acquittal in the criminal prosecution under s.14 Foreigners Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petitioner is an Indian citizen who was in India till 1951, dismissed from police service in mid-1950, went to Pakistan in 1951, and returned in 1956 on Pakistani passport but remains Indian citizen.
1960 acquittal under s.14 Foreigners Act creates issue estoppel that he is not a foreigner.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Issue estoppel from Mohd. Hanif Khan v. State AIR 1960 All. 434

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner is Pakistani national based on visa application stating migration in 1948.
Petitioner failed to prove he went to Pakistan only in 1951; frequent change of ground; burden on petitioner under s.9 Foreigners Act.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner did not go to Pakistan in 1948 but cannot establish he went only in 1951; matter within his knowledge, no evidence produced; frequent change of ground; mere statement not accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: When he went to Pakistan is a matter peculiarly within his knowledge and the produced no evidence in support of that statement.

court_reasoning.text: Even if married in 1949, cannot establish citizenship unless in India on 26-1-1950; no presumption of presence on that date; burden under s.9 Foreigners Act on petitioner to prove not foreigner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Under s-9 of the Foreigners Act whenever a question arises whether a person is or is not a foreigner the onus of proving that he is not a foreigner lies upon him.

court_reasoning.text: No issue estoppel: earlier was criminal prosecution, present is action under Foreigners Internment Order for deportation, not criminal prosecution; issue estoppel applies only between criminal proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions.

holdings.text: Petitioner has not discharged burden to prove he is Indian citizen and not a foreigner.
No issue estoppel applies as present proceedings are not criminal prosecution.

precedents_cited.relevance: Central Government to decide citizenship if in India on 26-1-1950 but went to Pakistan later
Central Government to decide citizenship if in India on 26-1-1950 but went to Pakistan later
Central Government to decide citizenship if in India on 26-1-1950 but went to Pakistan later
Central Government to decide citizenship if in India on 26-1-1950 but went to Pakistan later
Burden under s.9 Foreigners Act on person to prove not foreigner
Burden under s.9 Foreigners Act on person to prove not foreigner
Basis of magistrate's acquittal; Pakistani national entering before 1957 amendment not foreigner
Conflicting decision on nationality of pre-1957 entrant on Pakistani passport

precedents_cited.case_name: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab
Manipur Administration v. Thokchom Bira Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Issue estoppel only in criminal prosecutions

precedents_cited.case_name: Piara Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Issue estoppel only in criminal prosecutions

precedents_cited.case_name: Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federation of Malaya
precedents_cited.relevance: Verdict of acquittal binding in subsequent criminal proceedings
Crown precluded by estoppel by judgment in criminal proceedings

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Burden of proof on person to show not foreigner; basis of prior prosecution and acquittal

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Internment Order, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petitioner's arrest and confinement

outcome.summary: The writ petition under Article 32 seeking release from detention under Foreigners Internment Order, 1962 is dismissed as petitioner failed to prove he is not a foreigner and issue estoppel does not apply.

key_quotes.text: Under s-9 of the Foreigners Act whenever a question arises whether a person is or is not a foreigner the onus of proving that he is not a foreigner lies upon him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes burden of proof on petitioner

key_quotes.text: Issue-estoppel arises only if the earlier as well as the subsequent proceedings were criminal prosecutions.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The principle of issue estoppel is simply this that where an issue of fact has been tried by a competent court on a former occasion and a finding has been reached in favour of an accused, such a finding would constitute an estoppel...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of issue estoppel limited to criminal proceedings
